title: Sunbird Records
text:
Sunbird Records was an independent record label in the United States during the late 1970s and 1980s. <a href="Freddie%20Hart">Freddie Hart</a> had a few hits with Sunbird after he left <a href="Capitol%20Records">Capitol Records</a> in 1979. <a href="Earl%20Thomas%20Conley">Earl Thomas Conley</a> also recorded some hits with Sunbird while working with <a href="Randy%20Scruggs">Randy Scruggs</a>. <a href="Delbert%20McClinton">Delbert McClinton</a> recorded his hit "Not Exactly Free" with the label. <a href="Elroy%20Kahanek">Elroy Kahanek</a> was one of the label's employees. <a href="Bobby%20G.%20Rice">Bobby G. Rice</a> also recorded with the label. <a href="Sheb%20Wooley">Sheb Wooley</a> with Hi C. Lea recorded the single "Jackhammer Man" with the label in 1981. <a href="Price%20Mitchell">Price Mitchell</a> and <a href="Rene%20Sloane">Rene Sloane</a> did a recording on a 45 of "Mr. And Mrs. Untrue" and on the B side "Savin' It All For You" on Sunbird (he had recorded the 1971 <a href="Candi%20Staton">Candi Staton</a> song with Jerri Kelly in 1975). The same 45 was also released on <a href="Sunset%20Records">Sunset Records</a>.
Earl Thomas Conley recorded his Blue Pearl album with Sunbird. His song "<a href="Fire%20and%20Smoke">Fire and Smoke</a>" from the similarly titled album reached #1 on the country music chart in 1981 and he was soon signed to <a href="RCA%20Records">RCA Records</a>.
Freddie Hart had a Top 20 hit with "Sure Thing" on a Sunbird album in 1980 and then three Top 40 hits in 1981.
